title: Historian Bettany Hughes: My six best books
text:
Historian Bettany Hughes: My six best books Historian Bettany Hughes: My six best books BETTANY HUGHES, 49, is a historian and broadcaster whose television documentaries include Britain’s Secret Treasures, The Ancient World and The Spartans. Her latest book Istanbul: A Tale Of Three Cities (W&N, £25, is out now.   GETTY Bettany Hughes is a historian and broadcaster whose television documentaries 
THE ILIAD by Homer (translated by Robert Fagles) Penguin, £9.99 My desert island book. I first read it in ancient Greek at 15 with a boy I was in love with. It collapses time across 2,000-3,000 years, describing men and women in Asia Minor who dressed in animal pelts yet had ideas and dreams the same as ours. 
THE WHITE CASTLE by Orhan Pamuk Faber, £8.99 This came out after I first travelled to Istanbul at 18 and was enraptured by the city. He writes about the intrigues of Ottoman life. It made me fall in love with their culture even more. Related articles Some Freud for thought: Last night’s TV reviewed 
MADAME BOVARY by Gustave Flaubert Penguin, £8.99 I’ve never lived the life of an intelligent young woman who has affairs but I completely empathise with Madame Bovary. This was ahead of its time and it delivers brilliantly on the power of our internal lives. 
THE SONGLINES by Bruce Chatwin Vintage, £9.99 I was born with wanderlust and I’m never happier than when I’m on the road writing and researching. Chatwin was clearly of the same ilk. This traces Australian Aboriginal culture and drives home the power of nomadic life. The Man Booker Prize 2015 longlist Wed, July 29, 2015
